newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile blue chips close year with fresh decline.
newsitem.headline: Chile blue chips close year with fresh decline.

text.p: Ending a year of sharp declines, Chilean stocks closed lower in the last trading day of 1996, with the launch of supermarket chain D&S the only bright spot in otherwise flat trade, dealers said on Monday.
No clear trend is seen for the opening on Thursday, when trading is due to resume, they said. "With stocks so listless, it is hard to see much change on Thursday," one dealer said.
The bolsa closed early on Monday at 1400 local (1700 GMT) and will stay shut Tuesday for a financial holiday. It will reopen Thursday at 0930 local (1230 GMT) after New Year's Day.
The .IPSA index ended down 0.61 percent at 88.21 points.
The general .IGPA index shed 0.34 percent to 4,904.62 points.
Turnover climbed to 27.7 billion pesos, of which 21 billion pesos was from the sale of 90 million shares in D&S.
Blue chip stocks tumbled 17 percent in real terms in 1996. The decline reflected high local interest rates and a drought that hurt electricity stocks, traders said.

Investors fear that the drought will hammer earnings of Chilean power-generating companies, which are buying expensive power on the spot market to make up for the shortfall in production at their own hydroelectric plants.
Among the power companies, Endesa -- one of the bourse's biggest blue-chip losers this year -- touched a year-low of 210 pesos before recovering to close at 211 pesos.
Other losers included telecommunications company Entel, down four percent at 2,880 pesos, and papermaker CMPC, which fell 2.77 percent at 4,570 pesos.
Gainers included forestry company Masisa, up 2.14 percent at 191 pesos, and telecom Telex, which firmed 1.11 percent to 1,000 pesos.
